speaker: Daphne
text: No, really.  I've never had a serious boyfriend.  No-one's really been interested.

speaker: Niles
text: Men can be such pigs. [_starts making a swan out of the napkins Daphne is sorting out_]

speaker: Daphne
text: It's not that people weren't trying to fix me up.  Back in Manchester my mum was steering me toward Reginald Glower, the butcher's son.  Pasty little thing.  Never did take to him.  I suppose I like my gents more on the manly side. [_Niles flattens the swan_] Was that a little swan you made?

speaker: Niles
text: No, it was a B-52.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, Dad's done it again.  That was Dr. Jennings's office on the phone.  He's skipped his physical again today.

speaker: Daphne
text: Why, that little devil.  No wonder he didn't want me to go with him.

speaker: Niles
text: Frasier, you know Dad's intense aversion to doctors, you should have seen that he got there.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, well I didn't see you volunteering this afternoon.

speaker: Niles
text: Well, I couldn't.  I had my "fear of abandonment" workshop today, and I've already been a no-show twice.

speaker: Daphne
text: Wait 'til your father gets here, I'll give him such a piece of my mind.  _Eddie comes bounding out of the bedroom, bounces over the furniture and sits by the door._

speaker: Frasier
text: If only we had some way of knowing if he was about to arrive.

speaker: Martin
text: [_to Eddie_] Hey, how ya doin', boy? Yeah, glad to see you too.

speaker: Frasier
text: So.  How was your exam today?

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, you know.  Everything's pretty routine.

speaker: Frasier
text: EKG?

speaker: Martin
text: Perfect.

speaker: Niles
text: Blood pressure?

speaker: Martin
text: Textbook.

speaker: Frasier
text: Hope they took a full blood panel.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, yeah.  Told them to take two.  They're small.

speaker: Daphne
text: Ooh, let's have a look. [_Martin rolls up his sleeve_] Ooh, look at this.  A nice, big Band-Aid. [_she rips it off his arm_] Nice try!

speaker: Martin
text: Ouch!  What did you do that for?

speaker: Daphne
text: Dr. Jennings's office called to reschedule your appointment. You never showed up today.

speaker: Niles
text: Dad, this is ludicrous.  Why do you keep avoiding the doctor?

speaker: Martin
text: Because I feel fine.  I'll go to the doctor when I don't feel fine.  Besides, I don't like Dr. Jennings.  He's got a model of a colon on his desk, he keeps his tongue depressors in it.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, all right Dad, fine.  If you don't like him, why don't you go to see my doctor, she's one of the finest gastroenterologists in this city.

speaker: Martin
text: She?  Oh ho ho, no no.  No way.  If a doctor's gonna have me bend over, I want to look through my legs and see wingtips.

speaker: Daphne
text: Now now, we'll have none of that.  We women have been poked and prodded by male doctors for centuries.  I say it's high time you gents went to see a doctor of the opposite sex. See how you like waiting in that room - sitting there all naked and helpless and goose-bumpy.

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, surely you could recommend someone?

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles!

speaker: Niles
text: I'm sorry, my mind was somewhere else.  Rec... OH!  I know who you should see - Dr. Gary Newman.  His office is in my building, he has a very successful practice, I saw a Lichtenstein hanging in his office.

speaker: Frasier
text: Ooh, Lichtenstein.  He sounds perfect.

speaker: Martin
text: Alright, alright.  I'll make an appointment, I'll go see him.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, now just hang on a second there, mister.  I will make the arrangements and I will escort you personally.

speaker: Martin
text: Wonderful.  I can't wait.

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, stop grumbling.  It won't be so bad.  Well, unless you have to parade around the office in one of those gowns where your little bum peeks through the back.

speaker: Frasier
text: So Niles, what's Dr. Newman's number?

speaker: Frasier
text: ...Niles?  NILES!

speaker: Niles
text: I'm sorry, I must have drifted off again. _FADE OUT  Scene Two - Dr. Newman's waiting room. Frasier and Martin are waiting, along with an elderly lady._

speaker: Martin
text: My appointment was supposed to be half an hour ago, how much longer are we gonna wait for this guy?  Come on Frasier, let's get out of here.

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, Dad, just relax.  Read a magazine.  Oh, here, here. Take the Cosmo quiz.

speaker: Martin
text: [_reading_] "Are your nipples sensitive?"

speaker: Frasier
text: Would you mind doing that quietly, it's not an oral exam.

speaker: Martin
text: You haven't seen the second question.  Did you used to keep your patients waiting like this?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, just the compulsives.  It was part of their therapy. Relax there, I'll take care of it.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, my father Martin Crane had an appointment thirty minutes ago?

speaker: Receptionist
text: Yes, I'm sorry.  The doctor's running a little late this morning, but you'll be first up when he gets in.

speaker: Frasier
text: When he gets in?  My God, where's he coming from, Spokane?

speaker: Receptionist
text: Actually he has a long drive in from his weekend house at Lake Shalonne.

speaker: Frasier
text: Lake Shalonne?  Ooh, this guy must be terrific!

speaker: Martin
text: So?

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, relax.  He'll be here any minute. [_looking around_] You know Dad, I was just struck by one of life's little ironies.  I remember you taking me to the doctor, and now here I am taking you.

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah.  I remember when I took you for your first tetanus shot, you were about five or six.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh boy, was I scared.  I remember you holding my hand.

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah.  Bent over that table, dropped your little drawers. When the nurse gave you the shot, you took your mind off it by reciting the names of all of Puccini's operas.  Right then I knew you'd never be a cop.  Look, I'm serious.  I'm not staying any longer, let's go.

speaker: Frasier
text: All right dad, look, I'll check and see if there's someone substituting for him.

speaker: Martin
text: [_to lady_] What are you here for?

speaker: Lady
text: Lately I've been having this overall sluggish feeling.  It's hard even getting out of bed in the morning.  Not to mention the cold weather.  It's really making my joints hurt.  I've started to notice flaking spots on my skin.  What about you?

speaker: Martin
text: [_who wishes he hadn't started this_] I have sensitive nipples.

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad?  I'm afraid the doctor won't be able to make your appointment today.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, that's just great.  These big-shot doctors, they keep you waiting for an hour and then they don't even have the decency to show up!  What, play a little slow on the golf course today? That arrogant, inconsiderate jerk!

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, Dad, Dad -- Dr. Newman is dead.  He died an hour ago.

speaker: Martin
text: I'm sure he was a good man. **WELL, I'M LOUSY AT TENNIS...**  _Scene Three - KACL Frasier is talking to Roz._

speaker: Frasier
text: I mean, there he was, walking down his walkway this morning and, he bends over to pick up his newspaper and BANG! - he drops dead of a heart attack.  It's just... God, you know? I pick up my newspaper every day.  And the Sunday Times is very heavy, I'm thinking of canceling.

speaker: Roz
text: Well?  These things happen.

speaker: Frasier
text: "These things happen?"  Roz, how can you say that?  My God, this was not an old man, he was my age.

speaker: Roz
text: What am I supposed to say?  I guess I don't think of these things like you do.  Guess it's because you're forty-one and I'm... [_laughs_] not.

speaker: Frasier
text: Don't you ever think about you're own mortality?  Don't you ever think about dying?

speaker: Roz
text: Well, not me dying, but you know what I have thought about lately?  I've been dating this older guy, and what if... you know? [_Frasier doesn't_] We were in bed together and he dropped dead?  Well, it's not out of the realm of possibility. Sometimes he starts breathing very funny and I don't know if he's having a good time or if I've overexcited him to some dangerous level.

speaker: Frasier
text: Someone certainly has a very high opinion of herself.

speaker: Roz
text: Everybody's good at something.

speaker: Frasier
text: Why is it that every time we try to have a serious discussion, we end up talking about your sex life?

speaker: Roz
text: Because I have one. **A FAMILY MEETING**  _Scene Four - Apartment Martin and Daphne are there.  Frasier opens the door for Niles._

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, thank you so much for coming at such short notice.

speaker: Niles
text: Hello Dad, Daphne.

speaker: Daphne
text: Hello, Dr. Crane.

speaker: Niles
text: Yes, I came as soon as I could. [_for Daphne's benefit_] I was in the middle of my workout, but, I can always pump iron later.

speaker: Daphne
text: Well, I'll just pop into the kitchen and fix us a snack.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_taking a large folder over to the table_] Pump iron?  Niles, you don't even pump your own gas.

speaker: Niles
text: All right, all right.  Now what is all this nonsense about getting your affairs in order?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, it's this: Dr. Newman dying at such a young age really threw me for a loop.  I was trying to figure out why, and I finally realized that I hadn't made the proper provisions for my own death.

speaker: Daphne
text: [_entering with a bowl and a jar of peanuts_] Here we go.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh!  Here, allow me.  _He takes the jar but has even less success.  Frasier distributes files to each person._

speaker: Frasier
text: First, the pertinent information.  I've prepared copies for each of you.  The location and numbers of my bank accounts; [_Niles is still struggling with the jar_] my safety deposit keys; the number for my attorney... Niles, what are you doing? Oh, give me that!

speaker: Niles
text: [_to Daphne_] I loosened it for him.

speaker: Frasier
text: Now, the distribution of my personal possessions.

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, I really think this is a matter for family only.

speaker: Frasier
text: No, no Daphne, please, I'd like you to stay.  I'll come to you later.  Dad, Niles, I'd like you to put your names on these stickers, [_hands them over_] and place them on any object you'd like bequeathed to you.

speaker: Martin
text: This is crazy.  I'm not going to start putting my name on your stuff.

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, what happens if I die tomorrow, you and Niles end up in an argument about... well, that African mask, for instance?

speaker: Martin
text: It'll never happen.  Niles, you can have it.

speaker: Niles
text: I don't want it.

speaker: Daphne
text: Well, don't look at me.  I throw a towel over that thing when you're not home.

speaker: Frasier
text: Okay, fine.  Now we come to the issue of... my remains.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, jeez.

speaker: Frasier
text: I've arranged every detail in this easy-to-read binder. [_gives binder to Martin_]

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, this is taking it too far, would you look at this? [_reads_] "Burial; Casket; Caterers"?

speaker: Niles
text: Who are you using?

speaker: Frasier
text: Michaelson's.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, they're very good.  Excellent.  _They start discussing the wonder that is Michaelson's.  Martin tries to get a word in._

speaker: Martin
text: Excuse me.  Excuse me!  Are we about done?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, there is just one more duck to put in the row.  I've done some research and I've discovered that most unexpected deaths occur in the home.  And Daphne, this is where you come in, the actual finding of the body.

speaker: Daphne
text: Ooh, save the best part for me, eh?  Well, that's all right. I'm a health care provider. I've had my fair share of patients Die on me.

speaker: Martin
text: That's a comfort.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, perhaps dad's right.  Maybe we should just drop the subject.  Well, thank you.  This meeting has actually made me feel better, I think I can handle my mortality a bit better now.  Well, enough talk about death. [_produces a bottle of wine_] Let's celebrate life with a bottle of Chateau Certair '75

speaker: Niles
text: Oh no, not the '75, I can't let you do that, that's far too good for the likes of us.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, perhaps a bottle of Beaujolais Nouveau would be more appropriate.  _He goes to find the bottle.  Niles takes the bottle of '75 and puts a sticker on it.  Martin glares at him.  END OF ACT ONE  ACT TWO  Scene Five - Apartment Frasier is lying on the couch with his eyes shut and his fingers in his ears.  Eddie is watching him.  Martin enters._

speaker: Martin
text: Eddie?  Ah, there you are.  Come on, boy.  Frasier, what are you still doing up? [_no answer_] Frasier!

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, please, shh.  I'm trying to listen to my heartbeat. Amazing thing, the human heart.  You know, it can pump eighteen hundred gallons of blood through it each and every day, but the tiniest tear in the tiniest part of the tiniest artery and "poof," you're gone.

speaker: Martin
text: I thought you were all okay about this stuff now.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, so did I.  What is the matter with me?  I guess I thought that putting my affairs in order would help me to deal with this thing, but it hasn't.  I... I can't seem to get over the feeling that no matter how remote the possibility, something could happen to me.  Jeez, I'd miss so much.  I'd never get to see my son hit his first home run.  It'd be a terrible thing for a father to miss.

speaker: Martin
text: Tell me about it.  Look son, let me tell you something.  There was this time, a while back, seven or eight of us were on this drug bust.  We get the order to go through the front door, and the first guy took one.  He was dead before he hit the ground. When you're a cop, you've got to be able to handle things like that, but I... I just couldn't get over it.  Every time I had to go in a blind alley, or in a dark building, I just froze. And I knew if I kept being afraid to die, I'd never be able to do my job.

speaker: Frasier
text: So what did you do?

speaker: Martin
text: I just forced myself to forget about it.

speaker: Frasier
text: Just like that?

speaker: Martin
text: Just like that.  Next time I came across one of those doors, I went right through it. [_then_] The fact that I got shot in the hip was purely coincidental.

speaker: Frasier
text: You were this close to helping me there, Dad.

speaker: Martin
text: Look Frasier, just because some doctor dies doesn't mean you're gonna die.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, but he was just like me.  Highly educated, sophisticated, at the top of his profession; I saw a picture of him in a medical journal, he even looked like me.  Same determined chin, sweater vest and ever-so-slightly receding hairline.

speaker: Martin
text: Look, what do you know about this guy?  You don't even know his medical history.

speaker: Frasier
text: Actually, you're on to something there, dad.  Yeah, yeah. For all I know he could have had high blood pressure, popped pills, drank like a fish...

speaker: Martin
text: There you go, it could have been any of those things.

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm gonna find out what caused his heart attack.  That's the only way I can disassociate myself from him.  There's got to be some reasonable explanation. [_heads towards bedroom_] That's great, dad.  Actually, I do feel better now.

speaker: Martin
text: Frasier, you've got something on your bathrobe.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_discovers it's a sticker_] Niles... the vultures are circling. KRUGEL, FRAS, AND ALLEN  _Scene Six - Dr Newman's House All his family are there, dressed in black. The door is open._

speaker: Frasier
text: Hello?  Hello. [_he attracts the attention of one of the guests_] I called earlier, someone said Mrs. Newman would be here?

speaker: Allen
text: Oh, of course, please come in.  I'm Allen Freedman.  Gary was my cousin.

speaker: Frasier
text: Dr. Frasier Crane.  My sincerest condolences.  So, I didn't think Mrs. Newman would have company.

speaker: Allen
text: Oh, the family are sitting Shiva.

speaker: Frasier
text: Excuse me?

speaker: Allen
text: You're not Jewish, are you?  It's our version of a wake.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh -- oh, yes.  Oh, of course, of course.  I didn't realize that Gary was Jewish, you see.

speaker: Allen
text: You're kidding.

speaker: Frasier
text: Uh, well no.  Ah, well, you know, we were pretty close friends, spent a lot of time together -- well, never on Friday nights, of course - but ah, you know, maybe I should come back another time.

speaker: Allen
text: No no, please.  I'm sure Julie'd love to know that you came. She's right over there. [_points_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, she looks busy.  I can wait.

speaker: Allen
text: Of course.  If you'll excuse me? [_goes back to table_]  _Frasier notices a black drape hanging over a frame, and lifts it to discover a mirror underneath.  An older woman, Aunt Bobbie, sees him._

speaker: Bobbie
text: May I help you?

speaker: Frasier
text: Ah.  I didn't realize this was a mirror, I thought that maybe you were having an unveiling later.

speaker: Bobbie
text: You're not Jewish, are you?

speaker: Frasier
text: No, no.  My, my ex-wife is, though.  And, ah, so and thus my son is.  Which makes me, ah, sort of... well I guess you could say... [_gives up_] No, I'm not Jewish.

speaker: Bobbie
text: We always cover mirrors at a Shiva.  So those grieving don't have to be concerned with their own appearances.

speaker: Frasier
text: Ah.  Ah well, you look very nice.

speaker: Bobbie
text: [_relieved_] Oh, thank you.  It's been driving me crazy. I'm Bobbie, Gary's aunt.

speaker: Frasier
text: Dr. Frasier Crane.  My deepest sympathies.

speaker: Bobbie
text: You're the doctor with the radio show, aren't you?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, yes.

speaker: Bobbie
text: Did you know Gary well?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, yes.  Yes, yes I did.  Well I, there's so much more I wanted to know about the man.  You see, ah... well oh, I don't know, ah... how was his health before he died?

speaker: Bobbie
text: Excellent.  He was never sick.

speaker: Frasier
text: History of heart disease?

speaker: Bobbie
text: Oh, no.

speaker: Frasier
text: High blood pressure?

speaker: Bobbie
text: No.

speaker: Frasier
text: High cholesterol?

speaker: Bobbie
text: No.

speaker: Frasier
text: Do you know what his HDL was in comparison to his LDL?

speaker: Bobbie
text: No.

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm sorry.  I'm asking too many questions.  You know how doctors are, always looking for the answers to the mysteries of life.  _A woman enters, carrying a cake.  She's been crying.  Bobbie greets her._

speaker: Bobbie
text: Oh, Gail.

speaker: Gail
text: Aunt Bobbie. [_they hug_]

speaker: Bobbie
text: I know, I know.  Gail, I'd like you to meet a friend of Gary's. Dr. Frasier Crane.

speaker: Gail
text: Dr. Crane?  From the radio?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes.  I'm sorry for your loss.

speaker: Gail
text: I love your show. [_re: her tears_] Oh, I... I'm sorry about this.  It's just, ah, when I went to pick up this linseed tort I thought of Gary and...

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh?  So Gary had a fondness for fattening desserts, did he?

speaker: Gail
text: Oh.  You didn't know Gary very well, did you?  If he knew I brought this here, he'd kill me.

speaker: Allen
text: Yeah, Gary was a total health fanatic, a strict vegetarian. I used to play basketball with him every Sunday.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh.  Oh, so he was sedentary all week, then he was burning up the court on Sundays.  Well, that can be very straining on the heart, you know...

speaker: Bobbie
text: No, he played at least four times a week.  That is, when he wasn't at the gym working out.

speaker: Gail
text: Gary was in phenomenal shape.

speaker: Bobbie
text: He didn't smoke, never touched caffeine...

speaker: Allen
text: Did you know he had less than 10 percent body fat on him?

speaker: Frasier
text: My goodness.  Has anybody checked to see if he's really dead? [_this does not go down well_] I'm sure they did check, those people are very thorough.  Oh my, is that Krugle?  Excuse me.  _Frasier escapes.  He wanders round the room, offering his condolences to people and finds himself standing beside Mrs. Newman._

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm Dr Frasier Crane, I was a friend of your husband's.

speaker: Newman
text: Dr. Crane?  From...?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, the radio.

speaker: Newman
text: Gary never mentioned you.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, we weren't actually friends.  He had an office in my brother's building.

speaker: Newman
text: And you took the time to come down here.  His own partner didn't even stay fifteen minutes.  That's really sweet of you.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, actually I... there's a reason I came to talk with you.

speaker: Newman
text: Which is?

speaker: Frasier
text: It's about Gary.  About how he, er...

speaker: Newman
text: Yes?

speaker: Frasier
text: Look, I'm sorry I've bothered you.  Ah, I really just came to offer my sympathies. _

speaker: Newman
text: Oh no, wait.  Um, Dr. Crane?  I listen to you all the time, and uh -- well, maybe you can help me?  What would you tell someone who called into the show and said they can't get over why someone died?  I keep running this over and over in my mind and... I just can't understand how someone like Gary, who did everything right, can just die.  I can't make any sense of it.

speaker: Frasier
text: Mrs. Newman, I... I know you'd like me to come up with some grand answer to this whole thing.  But I, I don't have one. There are none.  Someone who consumes nothing but cigarettes and cheeseburgers all his life can live to be eighty-three, and someone who takes care of himself can die at forty-one. It's unfair.  Believe me, there's no explanation for it. Believe me, I've checked.  But, I suppose the best we can do is live for the little joys and surprises life affords us. You can't spend your life being obsessed with death.

speaker: Newman
text: You're not Jewish, are you?

speaker: Frasier
text: No.  No I'm not.  Well, thank you for letting me be here today.

speaker: Newman
text: Oh, thank you for coming, Dr. Crane.

speaker: Bobbie
text: Oh, Dr. Crane?  It was very nice what you said about living life for the little joys and surprises it can give us.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes.

speaker: Bobbie
text: Thank you.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_quietly, to himself_] If only I believed it myself.

speaker: Woman
text: Excuse me?  Um, this is clearly the most inappropriate thing I've ever done in my life, but... I was watching you, and um, I don't know if I'll ever get the chance to see you again, and something about you tells me that I'd like to.  Here. [_gives him her card_] If you'd like to get together sometime, give me a call. [_moves off_]  _Frasier leaves, his spirits lifted.  End of Act Two._
